questions.question: When I see someone for the first time in the morning, I should:

choices.answer: Say, "Good morning," and share a polite smile.
Keep walking without making eye contact.
Acknowledge them with my eyes and keep walking.
Express how tired I am, and complain about the time of day.

questions.question: Before leaving a room to go on break or at the end of the day, I should:

choices.answer: Say "Good morning!" and walk away.
Exit the room without acknowledging people still in it.
Leave my belonging behind and exit the room quietly.
Tidy up my area and say "See you later!" or "Goodbye!"

questions.question: If I need to enter a room, I am expected to:

choices.answer: Knock on the door and immediately walk into the room.
Knock on the door (open or closed) and wait for a response.
Open the door and greet the people in the room.
Stick my head in the door and ask if I can come in.

questions.question: What two words complete the phrase best: "May I go to the bathroom, _____?" "Of course" "_____"

choices.answer: "quickly" and "thank you"
"teacher" and "please"
"please" and "thank you"
"please" and "I'll be back"

questions.question: When two grown-ups are speaking, and I need to talk to one of them, I should:

choices.answer: Wait at a short distance until I'm noticed and addressed.
Wave from a short distance or say the person's name aloud.
Stand next to them and listen to their conversation.
Touch person on the shoulder and say, "May I talk to you?"

questions.question: If I need to get someone's attention, the proper words are:

choices.answer: Hey you!
Excuse me, _______________ (person's name).
Listen to me!

questions.question: If I have a negative opinion about something, the polite thing to do is to:

choices.answer: Talk to my parents or teacher about it and ask for theirs.
Share it with everyone even if it creates gossip.
Mock or exaggerate the situation in front of others.
Keep it to myself or share it with a friend in private.

questions.question: Unless it's to compliment another person, I should never:

choices.answer: Call them or text them via telephone.
Comment on their physical characteristics or behavior.
Look straight into their eyes.
Comment on a their family and loved ones.

questions.question: When someone's asks, "How are you?", the polite thing to do is:

choices.answer: Tell them how you are and then ask how they are.
Tell them how you are and stop the conversation.
Tell them all your problems and fears
Skip the question and ask them how they are.

questions.question: In front of adults, I should always avoid:

choices.answer: technical language
formal language
foul language
new vocabulary learned in class

questions.question: Making fun of others makes me look:

choices.answer: popular and tolerant
smart and creative
like the worst person in the world
weak and lacking empathy

questions.question: Giving people a nickname to make fun of them is considered by most adults:

choices.answer: rude
clever
funny
unimportant

questions.question: If an activity I attend is uninteresting to me, I should:

choices.answer: Tell all my friends and make my negative comments aloud.
Ask my teacher if I can leave the room.
Leave the room and tell the organizer you're sick.
Sit through it respectfully and quietly as best as I can.

questions.question: If I meet someone on the way, who is walking in the opposite direction, I should:

choices.answer: Bump into them and ignore the fact that they are there.
Acknowledge that I've noticed them with a hello or a smile.
Avoid contact without acknowledging their presence.
Move away without saying anything.

questions.question: If I run into anyone in a hallway, room, or station, I should:

choices.answer: Ignore them and mind my own business.
Say hello, even if I don't make conversation with them.
Turn around to leave and come back later.
Talk to them and waste time you should be using elsewhere.

questions.question: When an adult asks me a favor, I should:

choices.answer: Do it, but ask them to please not ask you again.
Tell them you are busy, but that you will do it later.
Do it without hesitating and grumbling.
Ignore them or tell them to ask someone else.

questions.question: When someone offers to help me, I should:

choices.answer: Thank them, and tell them what to do.
Leave them alone to do what you were doing.
Avoid contact and continue with what you're doing.
Thank them, and politely say you don't need help.

questions.question: If I need something that a friend has or is using, I should never:

choices.answer: Ask them if I can use it.
Reach over and take it without asking.
Say please before, and thank you after.
Take care of it appropriately.

questions.question: The appropriate behavior to get rid of garbage is:

choices.answer: Ask the person next to me do dispose of it for me.
Leave it behind for someone else to deal with.
Get up, walk to the garbage bin, and dispose of it.
Throw the garbage from a distance and hope it makes it.

questions.question: If I want to share my opinion during class, I should always:

choices.answer: Raise my hand and wait for my turn.
Tell my partner and start a private conversation.
Interrupt the teacher or my classmates.
Raise my hand and start talking automatically.
